title: How to Choose the Right Flour

steps.headline: Notice any specifications or modifiers surrounding the word "flour" in the recipe.
steps.description: Does it call for "flour", or does it call for cake flour, bread flour, or something special?

steps.headline: Read the rest of the recipe.
steps.description: Try to understand the role of flour in whatever you will be preparing. Here are some things to look for. Is the recipe primarily a yeast bread? Does it use yeast as the primary leavening (rising) agent? Yeast bread recipes usually also include a lot of kneading and rising. Does the recipe use mainly baking soda, baking powder, or cream of tartar as leavening? Does the recipe use flour as a thickening agent for a sauce or soup? Does the recipe call for a mixture of flours, for flours made of other grains, or for additional sources of starch (such as cooked potatoes or oatmeal)? Does the recipe call for only a particular part of the grain, such as the grain or bran?

steps.headline: Distinguish between whole grain flour and refined flour.
The top three flours there are in the world (the most common) are all-purpose flour, bread flour, and cake flour.
steps.description: Think about it this way, all-purpose is very refined, you will get the thing that you are after, but it is not always used like it is in the name. Bread flour is significantly chewy when used and it is best to use in bread because it yields a lot of protein. Cake flour has very little protein and mostly used in a lot of desserts when you need to use a flour that is lighter than all-purpose, and that is pretty much all you need to know about the different types of flours.
